conclusion: To find the temperature of the gas in state B, we need to use the ideal gas law.
The ideal gas law is given by the equation PV = nRT.
Explanation of variables in the ideal gas law: P is pressure, V is volume, n is number of moles, R is ideal gas constant, T is temperature.
Determine the number of moles (n) of the gas using the ideal gas law rearranged as n = PV/RT.
Given values from the image: P = 3 x 10^5 Pa, V = 2 x 10^-3 m^3.
Convert temperature from Celsius to Kelvin: T = 27 °C = 273 + 27 = 300 K.
Calculate n using the given values: n = (3 x 10^5 Pa)(2 x 10^-3 m^3) / (8.314 J/(mol·K) x 300 K).
Simplify the calculation: n = 6 x 10^2 Pa·m^3 / 2588.2 J/(mol·K) x 300 K.
Further simplify: n = 6 x 10^2 Pa·m^3 / 8264.6 J/mol.
Find the temperature (T) of the gas in state B using T = PV/nR.
Calculate T using the values: T = (3 x 10^5 Pa)(2 x 10^-3 m^3) / (0.069 mol)(8.314 J/(mol·K)).
Simplify the calculation: T = 6 x 10^2 Pa·m^3 / 5.76 J/mol·K.
Therefore, the temperature of the gas in state B is 100 K.
